titleproper.value: Guide to the Ernest Rymer Photographs and Other Material <num>PHOTOS.245</num>

publisher.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

addressline: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

creation.value: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace <date>2018-09-19T19:12:31</date>

corpname.value: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives

unittitle.value: Ernest Rymer Photographs and Other Material

extent.value: in 2 oversize flat boxes, 1 manuscript box, and 7 folders

abstract.value: Ernest Rymer (1908-1986) served as director of the Jewish People's Fraternal Order (JPFO), part of the International Workers Order (I.W.O.), after World War II until sometime in the 1950s. He was possibly director of the JPFO's youth division prior to his appointment as JPFO director. The collection mainly consists of photographs that document the various conferences, demonstrations, performances, and other activities of the Jewish Young Fraternalists, part of the Jewish Peoples Fraternal Order (JPFO), I.W.O.; the activities of the general JPFO, I.W.O.; and the activities of I.W.O. as a larger organization. The collection also contains a plaque awarded to Rymer and his World War II-era Navy uniform, as well as a number of political and/or commemorative buttons and pins.

p.value: Identification of item, date; Ernest Rymer Photographs and Other Material; PHOTOS 245; Box number; Folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.
Donated by Judith Rymer (daughter), 2007 and 2013. The accession numbers associated with this collection are 2007.001, 2013.015, and NPA.2007.034.
Rymer died in Manhasset, Long Island, NY in 1986 at age 77.

In addition to the photographs, there is also correspondence related to Rymer's Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request for his records, as well as the federal documents he received in response to his request. The collection includes a plaque awarded to Rymer by the International Federation of Professional and Technical Engineers, Local 66, as well as Rymer's World War II-era Navy uniform, dog tag, and Jewish War Veterans and Navy pins. A number of political and/or commemorative buttons and pins on a variety of topics are also present, including approximately 40 pins, a keychain, and some miscellaneous small artifacts from the Soviet Union.
